sections.title: The SOV Structure in Classical Tibetan
sections.content: Classical Tibetan, the language of Buddhist scriptures and philosophical texts, follows a Subject-Object-Verb (SOV) word order. This is fundamentally different from English (SVO) or French (SVO). Understanding this basic structure is essential for reading sutras, commentaries, and classical Buddhist literature. In Tibetan texts, you will see patterns like 'The Buddha the dharma teaches' instead of 'The Buddha teaches the dharma'.

example.note: Classic example of SOV: Subject (Buddha) + Object (dharma) + Verb (taught)
བདག (bdag) is the classical/formal 'I' used in texts

example.transliteration: sems can thams cad sangs rgyas kyi rang bzhin ldan
example.english: All sentient beings possess Buddha nature.
example.note: ཐམས་ཅད (thams cad) means 'all' and follows the noun it modifies
ལ (la) is a case particle indicating the object/recipient

example.transliteration: bdag gis dkon mchog gsum la skyabs su mchi
example.english: I take refuge in the Three Jewels.
example.note: Common opening phrase in Buddhist texts

example.transliteration: slob dpon gyis bstan bcos mdzad
example.note: མཛད (mdzad) is an honorific verb form

example.transliteration: byang chub sems dpas snying rje sgom
chos thams cad stong pa nyid
example.note: སྟོང་པ་ཉིད (stong pa nyid) = emptiness, fundamental Buddhist concept

example.english: The scholar translated the sacred text.

sections.title: Subject-Object-Verb Word Order
sections.explanation: In Classical Tibetan, the verb always comes at the end of the sentence. The basic pattern is: Subject + Object + Verb. The subject is often marked with the agentive particle གིས/ཀྱིས/གྱིས/ས (gis/kyis/gyis/s), and the object may be marked with other case particles like ལ (la) depending on the verb. This structure is fundamental to all Tibetan sentences, from simple statements to complex philosophical arguments in sutras and commentaries.

examples.note: This sentence structure appears throughout sutras when describing the Buddha's teachings.

examples.transliteration: bdag gis sangs rgyas la mchod pa 'bul
examples.english: I offer worship to the Buddha.
examples.note: Common devotional phrase. Notice how even with two objects, the verb remains at the end.
Past tense verb form. The SOV structure remains constant across all tenses.

sections.title: The Agentive Particle
sections.explanation: The agentive particle marks the agent or doer of an action. It has four forms that are used based on phonetic rules: ས (s) after ང/ན/མ/ར/ལ, གིས (gis) after other consonants, ཀྱིས (kyis) after palatalized consonants, and གྱིས (gyis) after ད and བ. This particle is essential in classical texts and helps identify who is performing the action.

breakdown.role: case marker - used because བླ་མ ends in མ

examples.note: གདམས་ངག (gdams ngag) are the essential spiritual instructions passed from teacher to student.

examples.transliteration: dge slong gis sdom pa bsrungs
examples.note: སྡོམ་པ་བསྲུང (sdom pa bsrung) - keeping vows is a central theme in monastic texts.

sections.title: Practice Exercises
sections.description: Apply your understanding of SOV structure with these exercises based on classical texts

keyPoints.text: Classical Tibetan follows Subject-Object-Verb (SOV) word order, unlike English
The verb always comes at the end of the sentence
The subject is marked with agentive particles: ས/གིས/ཀྱིས/གྱིས depending on the final consonant
The agentive particle form depends on the final letter of the preceding word
This structure is consistent across all classical Buddhist texts, from sutras to commentaries
Understanding SOV and agentive marking is the foundation for reading Tibetan scriptures
